expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 2.00 cycles. At this rate:
 - 50% of peak load performance is reached (64.00 out of 128.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 100% of peak store performance is reached (64.00 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.00 to 0.50 cycles (4.00x speedup).

header: 0% of peak computational performance is used (0.00 out of 64.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.details: All SSE/AVX instructions are used in vector version (process two or more data elements in vector registers).
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt: Your loop is vectorized, but using only 256 out of 512 bits (AVX/AVX2 instructions on AVX-512 processors).

gain.workaround:
- Read less array elements
 - Write less array elements
 - Provide more information to your compiler:
  * hardcode the bounds of the corresponding 'for' loop
gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt:
Performance is limited by:
 - reading data from caches/RAM (load units are a bottleneck)
 - writing data to caches/RAM (the store unit is a bottleneck)

potential.title: 512-bits vectorization
potential.txt: On some x86 processors supporting 512-bits vectorization, compilers are often too conservative and limit vectorization to 256 bits. Performance can then be improved by enforcing 512-bits vectorization, especially with many vectorized and high trip count loops. 512-bits vectorization performance overhead (compared to 256-bits) is generally lower on newer processors.
